repnme.cdata!:
Quality of education - Improving teaching
            and learning capacity in Malawi

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile focuses on the
            quality of education in Malawi. Malawi’s poverty reduction
            strategies identified the enhancement of human capital as
            one of Malawi's formidable challenges. In response to
            these challenges, the International Development
            Association’s approach included training of primary school
            teachers, provision of materials to secondary teachers and
            training of university lecturers at various levels. The
            project engaged the communities through the participation of
            parent-teacher associations in the procurement of learning
            materials, organization of school feeding programs, and
            promotion of good health and nutrition practices. As a
            result, children were reached with interventions, which
            included distribution of Vitamin A and iron, folic acid,
            de-worming, treatment of malaria and fever, and promotion of
            good health and nutrition practices.  The project improved
            learning through supply of basic learning materials to
            schools while strengthening the participation of communities
            in school management. At the primary level a new training
            college was constructed for primary teachers to increase the
            number of trained teachers annually. Finally, the project
            supported the development of a better policy framework and
            more comprehensive strategic plan

repnme.cdata!: Malawi - First Education Sector Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First Education Sector
            Support Project for Malawi were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            negligible, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            despite the sector needs and desire to address identified
            issues, realistic planning and budgeting is always important
            for successful and quality project implementation. The
            project scope had to be reduced substantially due to
            financial constraints. Education strategic plans are vital
            to the realization of effective donor coordination. They
            provide for a strategic approach to managing sector
            investments while consolidating national ownership for
            programs and projects. Support to policy and strategic plans
            development together with training and baseline surveys,
            yielded more long-lasting results including reforms in the
            institutional framework which had not been anticipated and
            contrary to normal practice. This could be attributed to the
            high Government commitment to reforms and its worth
            replicating elsewhere. Timely recruitment of project staff
            is essential for effective project implementation. Critical
            staffs were recruited mid-way through project implementation
            which led to delays in the implementation of some
            components. Project readiness should include the recruitment
            of critical implementation staff and be a condition for
            project effectiveness.

repnme.cdata!:
Malawi - First Education Sector Support
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The First Education Sector Support
            Project for Malawi will improve the conditions for service
            delivery and the quality of teaching and learning across the
            education system by: (i) improving the management, the
            number and quality of teachers, and (ii) strengthening the
            government's capacity to manage the system and
            financial resources. The closing date for project will be
            extended from September 15, 2010 until December 15, 2010. In
            a letter dated July 23, 2010, the Government of Malawi
            requested an extension of the project until November 15,
            2010. Finally, the team confirms that the requirements of
            Operation Policy/Bank Policy (OP/BP) 13.30 (closing dates)
            relating to the extension of closing dates have been met.
            Specifically, as required under the OP: (i) the project
            objectives continue to be achievable; (ii) the performance
            of the borrower and other project implementing agencies is
            satisfactory; and (iii) the borrower has prepared a specific
            action plan acceptable to the Bank to complete the project.
            The extension is necessary to ensure that all civil works
            and a few procurement cases can be finalized. A realistic
            and comprehensive action place is currently in place to
            ensure all needed work is completed by the December 15, 2010
            closing date.

repnme.cdata!: Malawi - First Education Sector Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The First Education Sector Support
            Project for Malawi will provide immediate financing to
            support the education sector in Malawi. This financing will
            be complementary to existing donor financed projects or
            programs to either fill a gap or complement these to
            generate a higher return on the overall investment. The
            project has the following six components: Component 1) will
            complement government and donors' efforts to improve
            quality and expand capacity of teacher development and
            training at all levels. Component 2) will improve the
            conditions of learning at selected secondary schools staffed
            with trained teachers or newly trained teachers. Component
            3) will provide a School Health and Nutrition package to all
            primary schools, which will include the following
            cost-effective interventions: distribution of vitamin A and
            iron-folic acid to school children under 10 years old,
            de-worming, treatment of malaria and fever, and the
            promotion of good health and nutrition practices. Component
            4) will supply basic learning materials directly to schools
            while strengthening the participation of communities in
            school management. Component 5) Capacity Building and Policy
            Development will cover: (i) national education policy
            consolidation and capacity building; and (ii) support to
            implementation of government decentralization policy in
            education. Component 6) will support the physical
            implementation and management of fiduciary and procurement issues.

3750592.trustfund:
TF021432-UN SPECIAL INITIATIVE FOR AFRICA,TF026408-PHRD-MALAWI: BASIC EDUCATION
            IMPROVEMENT PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
Malawi - Education Section Support Project
            : resettlement policy framework

abstracts.cdata!:
This is a resettlement policy framework
            for the Malawi Education Sector support Project, which
            improves educational quality by increasing the quantity and
            quality of teachers and strengthening government capacity to
            manage the system and financial resources. Social impacts
            are likely to occur during the construction and
            rehabilitation of educational facilities. When
            rehabilitating community day secondary schools, the
            Polytechnic Institute, and the Chancellor College, take care
            during the screening process to identify all possible land
            uses, for example, crop production or grazing at these
            facilities to ensure compensation. No social impacts are
            likely when Mzuzu University is rehabilitated. When building
            the Teacher Training College, social impacts may occur with
            land use changes along with the need to acquire land to
            accommodate building power distribution lines to connect the
            campus to the grid. Regarding the development and use of
            borrow pits as sources of construction materials, potential
            impacts include loss of access to economic activities and
            loss of livelihoods due to the need for land acquisition to
            develop new borrow pits. This report outlines the conditions
            which will determine whether a full or abbreviated
            resettlement action plan is needed, the applicable laws, the
            methods of valuing affected assets, the policy for
            compensation for property and crops, the organizational
            procedures for delivering entitlements, the grievance
            redress mechanisms, budget and funding arrangements, methods
            for community consultation, and monitoring arrangements.
